Award.AwardTitle: The Geochemical Processes Controlling Vacancy and Mn(III) Concentrations in Birnessite Structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Soils, sediments and natural waters may become contaminated by toxic metals from anthropogenic sources, such as mining and industrial wastes, vehicle emissions, lead-acid batteries, paints, etc., threatening public health and ecosystem. Birnessite, the dominant type of wide-spread manganese (Mn) oxide mineral in the environment, is a metal scavenger and can hold several percentages of toxic metals of its body weight, hence acting as an effective detoxifying agent. The ability of birnessite to scavenge metals, as well as other properties, highly rely on its structure and chemical composition that are affected by unknown geochemical processes. The main objective of this funded research is to identify the geochemical processes and discover how they take place step by step, how rapidly they happen, as well as whether and how they are affected by common environmental conditions. Results will benefit not only the fundamental research on critical geochemical and mineralogical processes, but also industrial applications of Mn oxides, such as fabricating high-performance birnessite as sorbents and oxidizers for pollution control and as semiconductor for harvesting solar energy in the photovoltaic industry. The proposed study will train students at different levels. The PI and a high school teacher will work together to develop a curriculum in earth science for high school students.

The extraordinary properties of birnessite are determined by Mn vacancy and Mn(III) concentrations in its structure. There is, therefore, a critical need to identify those geochemical processes that control birnessite vacancy and Mn(III) concentrations. In the absence of such knowledge, assessing contaminant fate and transport particularly in Mn-rich environments will remain challenging. We hypothesize that the reactions of Mn(II) with birnessite control the vacancy and Mn(III) concentrations, and that the reactions are subject to influences of solution chemistry and birnessite formation rates. Both microbially mediated and chemically-synthetic reaction systems will be employed. X-ray absorption spectroscopy, diffraction and atomic pair distribution function analysis, and high resolution transmission electron microscopy will be used to characterize birnessite samples in addition to wet chemical analyses. Results are expected to advance the current understanding while generating new knowledge of Mn oxide mineralogy and geochemistry and their impact on biogeochemical cycles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Manganese oxides, such as birnessite, are common minerals in natural environment that have strong oxidizing and metal-adsorption properties. They are so called metal scavengers. Thus, they play a big role in many geochemical and environmental processes, such as trace metal fate and organic carbon cycling in soils and sediments. The adsorption and oxidation reactivity of birnessite is controlled by its chemical composition and structure. Among many structural and compositional features of birnessite, Mn(III) and vacancy concentrations are the most important, because they affect metal adsorption capacity and oxidizing power of birnessite in many ways. Interestingly, Mn(III) and vacancy concentrations both vary in naturally occurring birnessite minerals, but it had remained unknown what geochemical processes lead to the variations. Addressing this question helps us understand the reactivity of birnessite and its geochemical and environmental role. We hypothesize that Mn(II) can reduce Mn(IV) in birnessite to produce Mn(III) which can accumulate in birnessite structure and thereby affect Mn(III) and vacancy concentrations. To test the hypothesis, we partially reduced birnessite by dissolved organic matter (DOM) to produce Mn(II) which in turn reacts with remaining birnessite to change its composition, particularly Mn(III) concentration, under various environmentally-relevant conditions

We found that high pH and high ratios of DOM to birnessite led to high Mn(III) concentration and low vacancy concentration in birnessite. However, when the ratio was very high (~ 10), low valence Mn oxides including MnOOH and Mn3O4, were resulted, which were further reductively dissolved by DOM. Regarding the impacts of co-existing cations, compared to Na+, Ca2+ and Mg2+ increased DOM adsorption on birnessite but did not affect DOM oxidation by birnessite; however, Zn2+ impose strong inhibition on DOM oxidation by birnessite. Accordingly, Mn(III) accumulated significantly in the structure of birnessite in Ca2+ or Mg2+ solution but not in Zn2+ solution. These results have important implications for understanding the variations of Mn(III) concentration and accordingly the reactivity of naturally-occurring birnessite.

The findings of this project were published in three papers with the Ph.D. student as the lead authors in top journals of the field. In addition, the project resulted in five co-authored papers with the PI or both PI and the student as collaborators. The student and PI also disseminate the findings by giving volunteer or invited talks in national conferences. Moreover, the PI was invited to give department seminars multiple times, for which a portion of the results from this project was also presented.

In addition to the scientific achievements, the project helped develop STEM workforces, particularly towards underrepresented groups. The project produced one highly trained Ph.D. in Earth and Environmental Science field, and supported two undergraduate interns (one was black female student) and two high school students (one was black male student). The students were given opportunities to improve their professional development, including presentations in conference sessions and symposiums, laboratory skills, learning state-of-the-art techniques in national labs, mentoring skills, writing skills, etc. The PI and the Ph.D. student also had a booth to educate the public about the importance of minerals in the environment, such as at the Women In STEM event that involved hundreds of female high school students.
